G.L. c. 218 \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218 §19 and c. 185C §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the District Court’s civil jurisdictional limits.

c. 185C \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218 §19 and c. 185C §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the District Court’s civil jurisdictional limits.

G.L. c. 186 \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186 §14, a landlord is prohibited from interfering, directly or indirectly, with the quiet enjoyment of a tenant’s premises.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 93A \u00a72 & \u00a79.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws c. 93A §2 & §9 (unfair or deceptive acts by landlords may constitute violations when interference is substantial, though not separately pleaded herein).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable for noise from adjacent premises where interference was foreseeable consequence of landlord’s actions).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court held that the landlords were liable for noise and disturbances emanating from a lounge they had leased to others where such interference with residential tenants’ quiet enjoyment was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ actions, and where the landlords had the right and ability to control the objectionable conditions. The opinion explicitly grounds liability on the foreseeability of the interference and the landlords’ control over the adjacent commercial use, matching the proposition that the landlord is liable for such foreseeable noise from adjacent premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.… The landlords introduced a commercial activity into an area where they leased premises for residential purposes.… The potential threat to the occupants of the nearby apartments was apparent in the circumstances.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (covenant breached where landlord’s acts substantially interfered with tenant’s enjoyment).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case does discuss the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but its holding is about the level of landlord fault required (at least negligence and notice/foreseeability), not about when landlord conduct constitutes a substantial interference with the tenant’s enjoyment. The opinion nowhere frames the rule as “covenant breached where landlord’s acts substantially interfered with tenant’s enjoyment,” and in fact concludes that a mere statutory violation (lead paint strict liability) does not automatically amount to a § 14 breach. Thus, it does not affirm the specific proposition cited.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (landlord liable for severe noise caused by activities within landlord’s control).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with a landlord’s failure to provide heat and resulting breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not address noise, severe or otherwise, nor does it discuss activities within the landlord’s control causing noise. The proposition about landlord liability for severe noise is therefore not supported by this case; that concept is more directly tied to Blackett v. Olanoff, which the court merely cites generally here.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is control[ling].’”

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929) (landlord duty extends to acts done with his permission or procurement).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that a landlord is liable when he authorizes acts that substantially interfere with a tenant’s enjoyment of the premises, even where the physical work occurs outside the leased space and is carried out reasonably. This directly affirms that the landlord’s duty extends to acts done with his permission or procurement, not just to his own physical intrusions. The reasoning and holding squarely support the proposition as phrased.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises and such a result is the natural and probable consequence of the acts so authorized, the landlord is liable therefor. Case v. Minot, supra.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (tenant entitled to damages for breach of quiet enjoyment caused by water leaks and persistent interference).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case squarely involves a tenant’s claim that repeated flooding and unsanitary water conditions in her apartment interfered with her quiet enjoyment, and the court holds that such flooding can constitute an actionable interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Although the specific $10,000 quiet-enjoyment damage award was vacated as duplicative, the court explicitly affirms that Gem is liable under § 14 because repeated, preventable flooding interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment, and that emotional distress damages flowing from that interference are recoverable. Thus it supports the proposition that a tenant may obtain damages for breach of quiet enjoyment caused by water leaks and persistent interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005) (breach where interference need not be intentional; it suffices that landlord failed to prevent foreseeable disturbance).
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment and states that the landlord must generally have notice of the interfering condition and act at least negligently in failing to alleviate it, which reflects that intentional interference is not required. However, the case does not hold that there was a breach under such circumstances; instead, it finds no breach because the landlord acted promptly and there was no serious interference. Thus, it does not support the proposition that there was a breach where the landlord failed to prevent a foreseeable disturbance; rather, it affirms the opposite result on these facts.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: "We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850-851 (1997). Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions... We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises."

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (constructive interference may qualify as breach).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord can be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on omissions—specifically, failing to take available measures to remove drug-dealing nontenants—where that failure results in serious interference with tenants’ use of the premises. This is a constructive, rather than direct, interference by the landlord: the landlord did not commit the criminal acts, but its inaction in the face of known conditions can constitute a breach. The opinion does not use the phrase “constructive interference,” but its reasoning fits that concept.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).proposition: Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013) (recognizing duty to avoid interfering with contractual quiet enjoyment rights).
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages and whether the plaintiff adequately pleaded veil piercing. It nowhere discusses quiet enjoyment, landlord-tenant rights, or any duty to avoid interference with contractual quiet enjoyment rights. Thus, citing Lipsitt v. Plaud for recognition of a duty regarding contractual quiet enjoyment is inaccurate and unsupported by this case.
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).relevant_excerpt: “In contrast, the right of an employee to sue for breach of contract or on a quasi-contract theory arising from the nonpayment of wages is so long standing and fundamental that it requires no citation. Lipsitt’s claims for breach of contract, or, in the alternative, quantum meruit, do not depend on proving a violation of some statutorily created right. His claims for unpaid wages due him under an employment agreement were cognizable well prior to the creation of the Wage Act’s private right of action in the 1993 amendments.”

Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).proposition: Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985) (statutory covenant provides for recovery without showing fault if interference occurs under landlord’s control).
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 93A injury and, separately, a quiet enjoyment claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not state that a statutory covenant allows recovery without showing fault whenever interference occurs under the landlord’s control. In fact, when addressing § 14, the court emphasizes that relief requires ‘serious’ or ‘substantial’ interference with quiet enjoyment and affirms denial of the tenant’s claim, rather than articulating a strict-liability rule based solely on landlord control. Thus, the proposition attributed to Leardi overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).relevant_excerpt: “Allisan claims that the judge erroneously concluded that G. L. c. 186, § 14, requires ‘substantial’ interference with her quiet enjoyment of the premises, and thus that he erroneously denied her claim under that statute. We disagree. ‘The phrase “quiet enjoyment” is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy ...’ (emphasis added). Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982). See Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (injury must be ‘substantial’ to afford ground for relief).”
